title: Installing the FTC SDK and Dependencies

sections.title: What is the FTC SDK?
sections.content:
The FTC SDK (Software Development Kit) is the foundation for all FTC Java programming. It provides the libraries, templates, and tools needed to write code for your robot. Keeping your SDK up-to-date ensures you have the latest features and bug fixes.

Learn more: FTC GitHub: FtcRobotController

sections.title: Cloning the SDK Repository
sections.content:
1. Open a terminal or GitHub Desktop.
  2. Clone the repository:
    git clone https://github.com/FIRST-Tech-Challenge/FtcRobotController.git
  3. Alternatively, download the ZIP from GitHub and extract it.

See: gm0: SDK Introduction

sections.title: Installing Required Dependencies
sections.content:
• Install the Java JDK (version 8 or higher). Download here
  • Let Android Studio handle Gradle and Android SDK installation during project setup.
  • Ensure your system meets the requirements: Windows 10/11, macOS 10.14+, or Linux; 8GB+ RAM; 10GB+ free storage.

Reference: FTC Docs: Android Studio Installation

sections.title: Updating the SDK
sections.content:
1. To get the latest features and bug fixes, regularly update your SDK:
  2. Open a terminal in your SDK folder.
  3. Run:
    git pull origin master
  4. If you have a fork, add the upstream remote and pull updates:
    git remote add upstream https://github.com/FIRST-Tech-Challenge/FtcRobotController.git
    git pull upstream master
  5. Resolve any merge conflicts as needed.

See: gm0: Updating the SDK

sections.title: Verifying the Installation
sections.content:
1. Open the FtcRobotController project in Android Studio.
  2. Build the project (Build > Make Project).
  3. Connect your robot controller device and deploy the default example OpMode.
  4. If the app runs and you see the OpMode on the Driver Station, your setup is complete!

Troubleshooting: If you encounter errors, check Gradle sync, device connection, and SDK versions. More help: FTC Docs: Connecting Devices

sections.title: Troubleshooting Common Issues
sections.content:
• Gradle Sync Issues: Check your internet connection and let Android Studio install missing components.
  • Device Not Found: Ensure USB Debugging is enabled and drivers are installed.
  • Build Errors: Try Build > Clean Project, then Build > Rebuild Project.

sections.title: Best Practices and Safety
sections.content:
• Always use the latest stable FTC SDK release.
  • Write your code in the TeamCode module; do not modify SDK core files.
  • Back up your code regularly using Git or another version control system.
